content:
Hello --

We want to apply the following restriction to the "performer" on the Immunization Resource ( https://www.hl7.org/fhir/immunization.html ):
There must be a performer and it is to be restrained to the PractitionerRole.

// performer 0.. Type: BackboneElement
//      +--------------> function 0..1 Type: CodeableConcept Immunization Function Codes (Extensible)
//      +--------------> actor 1..1 Type: Reference(Practitioner| PractitionerRole | Organization)

So, we do (we ONLY do this):

* performer.actor only Reference(PractitionerRole)

Is this correct?

TIA,
Hank

Hello Hank.
If you want to change cardinality (e.g. 0..1 to 1..1), you also have to state that in your FSH-file. The restriction to PractitionerRole looks fine to me.
Hope my answer helps you.

As @Mareike Przysucha said you need to set performer to 1..1. So add 

 * performer 1..1

To your fsh file.

@David Pyke -- I think he wanted performer.actor to be 1..1 (and performer cardinality to stay as is). So that should actually be:

* performer.actor 1..1
But if there MUST be a performer, then performer has to be 1..1
Okay, my fault. I didn't have the spec at hand.

@Mareike Przysucha - I made the same mistake! I was only looking at this text:

// performer 0.. Type: BackboneElement
//      +--------------> function 0..1 Type: CodeableConcept Immunization Function Codes (Extensible)
//      +--------------> actor 1..1 Type: Reference(Practitioner| PractitionerRole | Organization)

So to restrict the actor to only PractitionerRole, then he does need this line:

* performer.actor only Reference(PractitionerRole)

And... as @David Pyke noted, he also said "there must be a performer," so if he wants that reflected in the profile, then David is correct that he should also add:

* performer 1..1

Sorry for the confusion, @Hank Lenzi!
And sorry for doubting you, @David Pyke! I have learned my lesson now! ;-)

Thanks so much everyone for your thoughtful answers!
BTW, If I may say so, I think the FSH documentation is somewhat lacking in more convoluted examples such as the above.
-- Hank

Would it be correct to interpret the following

  • performer 0..1
  • performer.actor only Reference(PractitionerRole)
    as: "IF there is a performer THEN that role is to be played by the PractitionerRole" ?
Hank Lenzi has marked this topic as resolved.
Yes, that would say -- you can have 0 or 1 performers, but all performers (still max 1 in this case) must have an actor that refers to a PractitionerRole.
